title: Australia news live: Albanese expected to meet Zelenskyy in Rome; Watt says EPA needs ‘teeth’
snippets:
The environment minister has said establishing a federal environment protection agency was a ‘very high and immediate priority’. Follow the latest updates live

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Liberals must ‘build from the bottom up’ after election disaster – Ruston

Asked why the Liberals were now reviewing their embrace of the Paris climate agreement under the former government of Scott Morrison, Ruston says the walloping voters handed the party meant “absolutely everything” was up for review.

To be quite frank, we have to build from the bottom up again because that election result was quite disastrous for the Liberal party and we need to be open and honest with ourselves about what we need to take forward so that we are meeting Australia where they are and not talking about where we are.

Clearly we need to be doing something different. I think, you know, keeping an open mind, making sure we’re honest and open with that analysis of what went wrong, and actually come out with a policy proposal and a modern Liberal party, still maintaining all of the values that we hold so dearly.

Oh God, no, no, anything but, please. We have been there before many times over the past 20 years or so and to reopen the climate wars, as you aptly describe them, is like reopening an old wound.

But there’s no secret there is a divergence of views in our party room about how we achieve that, but right now, I absolutely think the thing we need to concentrate on is making sure that people can afford their power bills, making sure that industry, as Innes points out, that they have confidence in our energy policy in Australia so they can’t to invest here.

We don’t want companies to go broke like we have seen. We don’t want companies offshoring like we have seen. I think one of the most important issues is to get, you know, solid feedback and make sure our energy policy is fit for purpose for modern Australia.

Continue reading...

titles: Australia news live: Albanese expected to meet Zelenskyy in Rome; Watt says EPA needs ‘teeth’
Australia news live: Albanese expected to meet Zelenskyy in Rome; Watt says EPA needs ‘teeth’
summary: The environment minister prioritizes establishing a federal environment protection agency, emphasizing its urgency. Following a significant election defeat, the Liberals are reassessing their stance on the Paris climate agreement and other policies. The party acknowledges the need for a comprehensive review and a shift in approach to align with public expectations and to address Australia's energy policy challenges, emphasizing affordability and investment confidence. This reflects a broader effort to modernize the party and its policies while avoiding past conflicts over climate policy.
constructiveness_reason: This news story is constructive as it provides a deeper understanding of the political landscape in Australia, particularly in relation to environmental policy. It reports on the potential establishment of a federal environment protection agency and the Liberals' reassessment of their stance on the Paris climate agreement. This information could be useful to readers interested in environmental policy and politics, and it highlights progress in addressing climate change.

title: US PGA Championship golf 2025: day three – as it happened
snippets:
• Scottie Scheffler opened up a possibly decisive lead with some almost flawless golf down the closing stretch at Quail Hollow
  • Official leaderboard

… so having given Scottie Scheffler the grandstand introduction, he double-crosses himself and sends his approach at 1 towards the gallery to the left of the green. He’ll have a hell of a chip from there, from thick rough over sand. A pleasing symmetry to this.

… so having given Rory McIlroy the grandstand introduction, he carves his second at 10 towards the gallery to the right of the green. He’ll have a hell of a chip from there, from thick rough over sand. Meanwhile his playing partner, the defending champion Xander Schauffele, leaves his approach short and right, and immediately hollers “Mud ball!” Ah yes, mud balls …

Continue reading...
titles: US PGA Championship golf 2025: day three – as it happened
summary: Scottie Scheffler took a significant lead at Quail Hollow with outstanding golf towards the end, despite a challenging shot at hole 1 where he sent his approach into the gallery. Concurrently, Rory McIlroy faced a similar difficulty at hole 10, also hitting into the gallery. Both players encountered tough recovery shots from thick rough over sand. The event also highlighted a moment with Xander Schauffele, the defending champion, dealing with a "mud ball" issue on his approach. The detailed standings and progress can be checked on the official PGA Championship leaderboard.
constructiveness_reason: While this story provides a detailed account of the day's events in the PGA Championship, it doesn't provide much in the way of actionable insights or deeper understanding beyond the specific event. It does, however, provide a useful context for those interested in golf, and highlights the progress and challenges of the players involved.

title: Clement hits walk-off single, Jays beat Tigers 2-1
snippets: Ernie Clement emerged for his post-game session with reporters on Saturday with a massive ice bag on his right throwing shoulder.
Ernie Clement's ninth-inning walk-off single to centre field lifted the Toronto Blue Jays to a 2-1 come-from-behind win against the Detroit Tigers on Saturday.
titles: Clement hits walk-off single, Jays beat Tigers 2-1
Clement hits walk-off single, Jays beat Tigers 2-1
summary: Ernie Clement, playing for the Toronto Blue Jays, secured a 2-1 victory against the Detroit Tigers with a ninth-inning walk-off single to center field on Saturday. Following the game, he appeared for interviews with a large ice bag on his right shoulder, indicating a possible injury concern. This performance contributed to a come-from-behind win for his team.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides basic awareness of a recent sports event, but it does not offer deeper understanding or actionable insights. It also does not report on solutions, improvements, or attempts to solve problems.

title: Austria wins 69th Eurovision song contest with Wasted Love
snippets:
Israel finished second, with Estonia third and the pre-contest favourites from Sweden fourth

Austria has won the Eurovision song contest after JJ triumphed in Basel with their song Wasted Love, an operatic ballad with soaring vocals that mutates into a club anthem for the finale. It is the third time the country has won, with JJ following in the footsteps of Udo Jürgens in 1965 and Conchita Wurst in 2014.

Switzerland, which hosted the first ever Eurovision song contest in 1956, was the venue this year after Nemo won in Malmö last year with their song The Code. Austria will be expected to host in 2026, with Vienna having twice held the competition before.

Continue reading...

Israel finished second, with Estonia third and the pre-contest favourites from Sweden fourth

Austria has won the Eurovision song contest after JJ triumphed in Basel with their song Wasted Love, an operatic ballad with soaring vocals that mutates into a club anthem for the finale. It is the third time the country has won, with JJ following in the footsteps of Udo Jürgens in 1965 and Conchita Wurst in 2014.

Switzerland, which hosted the first ever Eurovision song contest in 1956, was the venue this year after Nemo won in Malmö last year with their song The Code. Austria will be expected to host in 2026, with Vienna having twice held the competition before.

Continue reading...
titles: Austria wins 69th Eurovision song contest with Wasted Love
Austria wins 69th Eurovision song contest with Wasted Love
summary: Austria won the Eurovision Song Contest with JJ's song "Wasted Love," marking the country's third victory in the competition's history. The operatic ballad, which transitions into a club anthem, secured first place in Basel, Switzerland. Israel, Estonia, and pre-contest favorites Sweden finished second, third, and fourth respectively. This win follows Austria's previous victories in 1965 and 2014. Switzerland, hosting the event this year, had previously hosted the first Eurovision in 1956. Austria is expected to host the next contest in 2026.
constructiveness_reason: The story provides awareness about the Eurovision Song Contest and the winner. However, it does not provide actionable insights or deeper understanding. It also does not report on solutions, improvements, or attempts to solve problems.

Additionally, an Ohio derby took place with Columbus Crew hosting FC Cincinnati, featuring a match-up of third against first in the Eastern Conference.

title: Magenta Auroras and Satellite Chaos: The Solar Storm That Hijacked NASA’s Drill
snippets: A surprise solar storm turned a NASA simulation into a real-world space weather crisis. As the Gannon geomagnetic storm struck Earth, it disrupted satellites, grounded flights, heated the atmosphere to extreme temperatures, and even shook up Mars. Auroras danced in skies far from the poles, satellites scrambled to stay in orbit, and a new radiation [...]
titles: Magenta Auroras and Satellite Chaos: The Solar Storm That Hijacked NASA’s Drill
summary: A surprise solar storm, known as the Gannon geomagnetic storm, hit Earth, disrupting satellites, grounding flights, and heating the atmosphere to extreme levels. This event also affected Mars and caused unusual magenta auroras to appear far from the poles. Originally coinciding with a NASA simulation, the storm turned into a real-world space weather crisis, complicating satellite operations and showcasing the potential chaos such solar events can cause.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides a deeper understanding of the impact of solar storms on Earth and Mars, highlighting the potential chaos they can cause. It does not, however, offer actionable insights or report on solutions or improvements.

title: Eruption Loading: New Volcano Warning System Hears the Earth Before It Blows
snippets: Oxford researchers found that changes in shear-wave splitting can predict volcanic eruptions and their severity. The signal shifted noticeably before a major eruption at Ontake Volcano, offering a promising early warning tool. A new study led by Professor Mike Kendall from the Department of Earth Sciences has explored a novel monitoring method for providing early [...]
titles: Eruption Loading: New Volcano Warning System Hears the Earth Before It Blows
summary: Researchers at Oxford University have developed a new volcano warning system that can predict eruptions and their severity by detecting changes in shear-wave splitting. This method was notably effective before a major eruption at Ontake Volcano in Japan. The study, led by Professor Mike Kendall, introduces a promising tool for early volcanic eruption detection, enhancing safety measures for potentially affected areas.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive as it reports on an innovation that can predict volcanic eruptions, thereby enhancing safety measures. It gives the reader a deeper understanding of the technology and its potential benefits.

title: The Next Earthquake Is Long Overdue: New Research Reveals Wasatch Fault More Dangerous Than Previously Believed
snippets: A new paper explains how the properties of fault rocks and geologic events that took place over a billion years ago could signal concerning seismic activity for Utah’s population center. Utah’s Wasatch Fault extends about 240 miles along the western edge of the Wasatch Mountains, from southern Idaho to central Utah. It runs through Salt [...]
titles: The Next Earthquake Is Long Overdue: New Research Reveals Wasatch Fault More Dangerous Than Previously Believed
summary: New research indicates that Utah's Wasatch Fault, a 240-mile fault line running from southern Idaho to central Utah, is more dangerous than previously thought. The study highlights that the properties of fault rocks and geological events dating back over a billion years suggest an increased risk of seismic activity for Utah's population centers located along the fault. This finding suggests that the area may be overdue for a significant earthquake, raising concerns for the safety and preparedness of the region.
constructiveness_reason: This story increases awareness about the increased risk of seismic activity in the Wasatch Fault region. It provides a deeper understanding of the geological factors contributing to this risk, but does not offer actionable insights or report on solutions to the problem.

title: The Winter Vitamin D Crash – And the Workout That Prevents It
snippets: New research shows that staying active in winter doesn’t just keep you fit—it also protects your vitamin D levels. The sun might be shining now, giving our vitamin D levels a natural boost, but not long ago we were in the depths of winter. During those colder, darker months, sunlight is limited, and vitamin D [...]
titles: The Winter Vitamin D Crash – And the Workout That Prevents It
summary: New research indicates that maintaining physical activity during the winter can help preserve vitamin D levels, which typically drop due to reduced sunlight exposure in the colder, darker months. This finding suggests that exercise can be a crucial factor in preventing the seasonal decline in vitamin D.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it provides actionable insights for readers on how to maintain vitamin D levels during winter months. It also reports on new research, contributing to the reader's understanding of the relationship between exercise and vitamin D. It increases awareness about a health issue that affects many people during the winter.

title: Is Your Salt Habit Secretly Fueling Depression?
snippets: Too much salt doesn’t just affect your heart—it may also impact your mood. Scientists discovered that high-salt diets in mice led to depression-like behavior through immune system activity. Cutting out certain immune cells reversed the symptoms, pointing to new ways we might treat or even prevent depression. High-Salt Diet Linked to Depression A new study [...]
titles: Is Your Salt Habit Secretly Fueling Depression?
summary: A recent study has found that high-salt diets can lead to depression-like behavior in mice by affecting the immune system. Researchers discovered that eliminating certain immune cells could reverse these symptoms. This insight suggests potential new methods for treating or preventing depression linked to high salt intake.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive because it gives readers a deeper understanding of the potential link between high-salt diets and depression. It reports on new research and potential methods for treating or preventing depression related to diet, contributing to awareness and understanding of mental health. However, it falls slightly short of a full score as it does not provide actionable insights for readers to apply in their daily lives.
